result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

2:07 PM Defendant Erick Ernesto Rodriguez Lopez in court in person with Sworn Spanish interpreter Victor Gonzalez appeared in court in person as interpreter for defendant. Attorney Joshua Patrick Grube appeared in court in person. Noah M Tylenda appeared in court in person for the State of Wisconsin. Officer Kailey Kinsella sworn testimony taken in court in person; Witness identified the defendant. Court takes judicial notice of bonds in cases 21CF3 and 21CF576. State moves for bind over, defense objects. Court finds probable cause and binds Defendant over for filing of an Information. Information filed, copy to Defendant's attorney, reading waived. Defendant's attorney pleads not guilty and jury trial to be set, attorney reserving but not demanding a speedy trial, bond to continue.
Preliminary hearing on May 9, 2022 at 02:00 pm.
